snippet: Diplomats often disappear behind closed doors. But not even being allowed to see the doors close sets something of a new standard.
abstract: Reporter's Notebook; reporters are banned from entering Egyptian Pres Abdel Fattah el-Sisi's palace during his meeting with Sec of State John Kerry, setting new standard of secrecy in dealings with United States' closest Arab ally.

byline.contributor: David E. Sanger is a national security correspondent in The Times’s Washington bureau. Follow him on Twitter @SangerNYT. Declan Walsh contributed reporting from Cairo.

lead_paragraph: Diplomats often disappear behind closed doors. But not even being allowed to see the doors close sets something of a new standard.

headline.main: Kerry Meets Egypt’s Leader, and Where Are Reporters? Corralled at the Airport
headline.print_headline: Kerry’s in Cairo, and Where Are Reporters? Back at the Airport

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
